data.text: Contents
Introduction

Mid and South Essex Foundation Trust (MSEFT) has a duty to provide training which is statutory (required by law to assure the maintenance of services) and mandatory (organisational requirements to limit risk and maintain safe working practice).

MSEFT is committed to developing a workforce that has the necessary knowledge, skills, competencies and behaviours to deliver an outstanding service to our patients, families and their carers. The Trust is also committed to creating opportunities to follow a career at MSEFT through experiential learning in the workplace or through members of staff being granted time away from their normal duties to pursue specific educational objectives. This Policy outlines the mechanism by which this study leave is granted.

Study leave is defined as a period of paid or unpaid time in which a member of staff takes time away from their own role with the aim of developing their knowledge and practice. This may be achieved through a variety of approaches which are increasingly more blended with on line or virtual learning as well as face to face clinical skills based training or classroom attended courses. Study leave will be agreed when education or training is clearly identified as beneficial for improved patient care delivery, service development or personal career progression within MSEFT.

Identifying education and training should be completed in line with Appraisal and personal development plans. For Professional Registrants, evidence of Continued Professional Development (CPD) Education is essential for re-validation with their professional bodies every three years. Health Education England (HEE) provide CPD funding equivalent to £1000 per eligible professional registrant for their revalidation cycle.

The policy applies to all staff in relation to statutory training however, mandated training and professional and commissioned education and approval of study leave applies to the non-medical workforce for the purpose of this policy. For Trade union study activities, refer to the Time off for Trade Union Policy.
Scope

The purpose of this document is to support the aims of the Trust's Education Strategy to create an environment in which all staff are supported and developed to become self-directed learners and creative problem-solvers, skilled, competent and effective team members, who can adapt positively to meet rapidly changing patient care and service delivery needs.
Outline the mechanism and the arrangements within which non-medical staff employed by MSEFT may apply for, and be granted, study leave:
MSEFT Bank staff are not eligible to be considered for funding for external courses.
Promote consistency and fairness in the availability of training and education offered to all staff within the Trust.
Promote the apprenticeship and work based learning opportunities to increase vocational training and development.

Detail the processes for staff to receive training, learning or development, the responsibilities of the parties involved and to clearly define the different areas of training and education available in the Trust.
The scope of this document covers essential training and professional and commissioned education:
Statutory Training (Health and Safety Legislated) for which paid time will be given to complete and affects all staff groups, for example Fire and information governance training.

Mandatory Training (Trust determined) for which paid time to complete will be given however the training subjects will differ depending upon the individuals training needs analysis or the training needs analysis of the staff group.
Professional and commissioned education for which paid time to complete will be dependent upon a criteria of the training being (1) Essential (2) Desirable or
(3) Personal.
Definitions

table_items.text: The Apprenticeship Levy is a UK tax on employers which can be used to fund apprenticeship training. It is payable by all employers with an annual pay bill of more than £3 million at a rate of 0.5% of their total pay bill
Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust
Training that is not required by law but is mandated by the Trust as needs to be completed to fulfil CQC or National Service Frameworks etc. This will vary by employee role

Training that is legislated in law and all staff are expected to be compliant in. This would normally include subjects such as those covered by The Health and Safety executive, Fire Training, safe moving and handling and subjects such as Information Governance

Required by the individual to be able fulfil their role. The manager may identify that the training is required by the Trust and the individual is asked to undertake the course. This would be 100% paid study leave for the duration of the course

Not essential to be able to do the role. The individual and/or manager may identify this as a ‘nice to have'. There is an expectation that 30% of the commitment would be met by the individual and this could either be as a portion of annual leave given up to attend the course and the Trust pays the course fees, or the individual self-funds the course and negotiates paid time off from work to attend, or a combination that suits the service but supports the individual's learning..

Identified by the individual as part of their own career development. Manager might support the request as a retention initiative but it is not essential or desirable to service delivery. In these cases a 50% contribution in either time or course fees may be requested of the individual
The team who commission and coordinate training and education funded via Health education CPD funding or the apprenticeship levy

Regulates professions: Arts therapists Biomedical scientists Chiropodists / podiatrists Clinical scientists Dietitians, Hearing aid dispensers Occupational therapists Operating department practitioners Orthoptists Paramedics Physiotherapists Practitioner psychologists Prosthetists / orthotists Radiographers Speech and language therapists

HEE supports healthcare providers and clinicians in planning and commissioning education and training. HEE provide limited ring-fenced CPD funds for professional non-medical registrants education and will supplement Trust funding to develop the workforce in line with NHS strategy
The Trust frequently arranges training and education sessions for specific staff groups, especially to meet commonly-required needs, e.g. clinical skills training.
Some of these are led by external bodies but occur within the Trust. Normally, study leave for external courses and training will not be approved if an in house solution exists

The term manager is used to refer to the person responsible for the day to day supervision of an employee, who also carries out the individuals performance review and to the line manager/service manager.
The regulator responsible for setting standards and for the quality assurance of the Nursing and Midwifery professions.
This is the Trust's process whereby staff are appraised on an annual basis and a plan of training is discussed for the development of the individual
Anybody working on behalf of the Trust whether permanently employed agency, bank, locum, contractor, volunteer, student or apprentice.

An approach that will include different modes of delivery of training and education. This may include on-line content and face to face or a blend of multiple methods rather than traditional classroom based courses.

The full cost of the training fees is funded through the apprenticeship levy, these commissioned courses cover a variety of subjects up to Masters level education for all staff groups and are not restricted to entry level jobs. 20% of the training is undertaken as paid off the job study leave. The remaining 80% commitment is undertaken in practice and own time with supervision.

This is a specific, time-limited, defined, period during which an employee is authorised to be absent from their normal working duties in order to participate in an event which has educational, training and/or developmental merit Many work-related activities have an educational component, or result in learning as a component element, e.g. attendance at Schwartz Rounds, MDT, governance meetings, and ward or specialty meetings. These are an integral part of service delivery and are not considered Study Leave periods. Not all scenarios can be predicted however, in general, if the activity is primarily aimed at education and training and results in the requirement to be unavailable for normal work duties, it will fall into the definition of Study Leave.
Trust staff designated as responsible for a specific topic or topics including the associated compliance.
This is a process which specifies training required for roles, rationale for doing and refresher periods and is renewed in response to emerging national guidance and priorities.

Many staff learn key skills in the work-place whilst under a degree of supervision. All will gain valuable experience and become more confident with time. This type of learning is becoming more common as part of apprenticeship programmes.
The Trust digital learning platform through which all on line, e-Learning and training is done. The MSE FT learning system is known as LEARN

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Trust Board

It is the responsibility of the Trust Board to ensure the implementation of the MSEFT study leave policy. It needs to be confident that there are controls in place to ensure that appropriate training/education opportunities are developed and delivered which are consistent with the needs of the organisation, and are deliverable within the resources available.
General and Service Managers

General and service managers will ensure that this policy and any revisions are disseminated to staff within their Directorate and that all requests for study leave and funding are assessed in line with the procedures laid out in this policy.
Line Managers/Supervisors

Line Managers/Supervisors will be responsible for identifying training needs through appraisal and in ensuring all staff have up to date personal development plans. In association with their employee, they will identify relevant opportunities for meeting their learning needs, through local/in house training, academic study, or by arranging on the job coaching or shadowing, mentor support or preceptorship. The line manager/supervisor will negotiate attendance on and funding of programmes appropriate to needs of the individual and sign off study leave once agreement is reached. The line manager/supervisor will discuss the expected outcomes with participating staff and help them to understand how the activity links to Trust, department and individual objectives and maintain a record of all development activities and evaluation of its effectiveness in meeting individual and service development needs.
Individual staff members

Where full or partial funding has been provided by the Trust to complete an externally provided course, the employee will agree to remain in employment of MSEFT for 1 year following completion. If individuals do not fulfil this undertaking, this will result in pro rata repayment of the course fees (in twelfths) unless there are mitigating circumstances on appeal. The only exception to this repayment of courses are apprenticeships which are governed by the Government's Education and skills funding agency (ESFA).

table_items.text: Study Leave allocation to be given by Trust
Training that is legislated in law and all staff are expected to be compliant in
Training that is not Health and Safety law but is MANDATED by the Trust as needs to be completed to fulfil CQC or National Service Frameworks etc
Essential in that the individual cannot carry out their job without it.
Desirable in that it would be beneficial to the individual but it is not essential to be able to the job and the Trust doesn't require it per se
Full if individual contributing 30% of their own time to attend the course
Personal in that it is beneficial to the individual from an interest and career pathway point of view but not essential to delivery of the service.
Negotiable. Individual may be asked to contribute up to 50% of the course
apprenticeships which are governed by the Government's Education and skills funding agency (ESFA)

data.text: Professional and commissioned education (PCE) Team

The team who commission and coordinate training and education funded via Health Education England including CPD funding or the apprenticeship levy is the PCE Team. They are responsible for collating a yearly investment plan on behalf of the Trust to submit to Health Education England for CPD funding. The commissioning cycle will commence in February for courses to commence in the academic year September to August. All non-medical staff will be considered and funding via HEE, Trust or Apprentice levy will be streamed and apportioned. Eligibility for funding is dependent upon all criteria being met and supported up to the limitations of available budget. The PCE team will check that the individual is compliant in statutory and mandatory training before progressing the study leave form, The Learning management system (LEARN) will be used to determine compliance and provide a learning record.
MSE FT Education and Training Board
The Trust Education and Training Board will be responsible for the oversight and direction of multidisciplinary education and training in relation to this policy.
Identifying the need

Once a member of staff is up to date with their Essential Training, they are able to request Study Leave for other learning opportunities. The first step is to identify the need. This should be supported by the Personal Development Plan agreed in the most recent annual appraisal. The "need" should then be prioritised into Essential or Desirable or Personal. Where a member of staff has requested a course which is available via an apprenticeship standard, this will be the route by which funding is considered and granted.
Essential

Education or training that is essential for the person to meet their job/role requirements and/or competency framework. Without this specific need being met, the staff member will be unable to fulfil their job requirements or there will be a substantial risk to patient safety or service provision.
Desirable

Applications for Study Leave that will result in an improvement in quality of care or patient safety but are not required to fulfil the applicant's role will be deemed as non-essential (desirable). The individual staff member will be supported to develop their role and become more productive. These study leave applications may require the approval of the Divisional Senior management group (Head of Nursing, Divisional Director of Nursing, and Manager) who will be asked to confirm this by a member of the Education Department.
Service commitments and continuity

Staff must not cancel any clinical or service commitments until their Study Leave and funding has been formally approved. In all cases where Annual Leave or other absence is planned to run consecutively with a period of Study Leave, this must be made clear by the applicant in the comments section on the online application form, so the total proposed period of absence is identified and approved within their Division.

When study leave has been approved, staff are normally entitled to receive a financial contribution to the associated costs, e.g. travel, subsistence, course fees, registration/examination fees. The level of payment will be in line with that agreed in National Terms and Conditions of Service. All travel, accommodation and subsistence fees should be considered for funding from within Divisional budgets. The Education and Training budget cannot be used to pay such expenses.
Programmes with research elements

The Trust fully supports the value of research elements within education programmes. However, dissertation topics at Masters Level and above are expected to make a contribution to the work of the Trust. All staff are expected to agree the focus of their proposed dissertation theme with their Manager to determine its relevance to the work of the Trust. Doctoral level thesis subjects should be fully supported by the appropriate Manager and discussed with either the Chief Nursing Officer or Chief Medical Officer.

All Masters and Doctoral level students, including those on taught Doctoral courses will be expected to submit for publication at least one paper in a peer reviewed journal within one year of completion

For courses lasting more than one year (e.g. Masters, Doctorates), approval will only be given subject to satisfactory progress. Consideration for course fees will only be provided on an annual basis dependent upon the applicant passing the required assessments/examinations and funding availability. MSEFT will not fund an extension of the course or re-sits. Where staff do not complete a course (including projects, assignments etc.) for which funding has been granted, requirement to repay 100% of the award will be considered.
Training requirements
To be implemented to all areas where staff have access to study leave.
Ensure dissemination is undertaken in a timely manner.
Inform all managers of study leave policy via email.
All staff to be made aware of the policy on induction to area of work if new to the Trust.
All existing staff to be made aware of policy by manager.
Ensure familiarity with the Learning Management System for learning records.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

Health Education England Quality Team. Trust Education and Training Board PODC
Compliance with the statutory and mandatory Training Requirements
Levy trajectory and compliance to public sector target
Trust Education and Training Board PODC

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the HR Policy Working Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the HR Policy Working Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment

The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. This policy has been equality impact assessed to ensure that the guidance provided does not place at a disadvantage any service, population or people and culture over another. (Refer to appendix 3)
Study Application and Learning Agreement

Section 2: Learning Activity Agreement (Does not apply to Apprenticeship programmes)
By signing this agreement the employee and manager are both in agreement to: Manager and Applicant
Inform the Trust of any issues which arise during a course of study supported by MSE FT. Such issues may include, but are not limited to:
Failure of a course, or part of a course at any of the attempts
Plagiarism or other investigations
Conduct Issues

Absence from the course – unauthorised absence from agreed study leave such as non- attendance at agreed study days could be considered as fraud and action will be taken by the Local Counter Fraud Specialist and the Trust to recover monies lost through such action.
The line manager must ensure the follow up action will be taken as appropriate
Applicant

As an employee, applying for study funding and leave, I agree, if required, to repay a proportion of the cost and study time incurred. At the Trust' discretion, this could be repaid either through time owed/annual leave or direct financial payment. I may incur costs in the following circumstances:
If I choose not to complete a course, or am excluded from completing a course through my actions.
If I undertake a programme of study, and decide to leave the Trust prior to completion
OR

If I leave the Trust prior to completing a required minimum period of service following completion of the course, repayment of course fees will be required on the following basis as outlined in Table 1 (below), as will repayment for a proportion of study time taken.

The decision to discontinue a course must be discussed with both the course leader and line manager prior to the final decision to ensure that all measures are put in place to support the employee to complete.

table_items.text: Minimum period of service required following
1/12th for every month remaining within the time frame

data.text: Table 1
The decision to reclaim costs in accordance with the above table will be at the discretion of the Trust. Each case will be considered on an individual basis.

If the cost of a course is paid in advance and the employee subsequently does not commence, all effort must be made to fill the place appropriately. If the place still remains unfilled a charge appropriate to the cost of the programme may be incurred by the original member of staff/directorate.

If the employee leaves the Trust prior to or following completion of the course to commence employment with another NHS organisation, there is no requirement to repay course fees or time taken for study.
I understand that in accepting the offer of financial assistance from the Trust for the course specified that in the event of either:
(a) leaving the course either voluntarily, or by exclusion
(b) leaving the Trust prior to completion of the course
(c) leaving the Trust following completion of the course but prior to completion of the required minimum service requirement as specified above in Table 1
I will repay to the Trust the relevant charge / proportion of course fees / study time as specified above.

I understand and agree that the Trust may recover any amount (in accordance with the above) from salary payment made to me prior to my date of termination. Where any sum remains outstanding at date of leaving I understand that a debtor account will be raised and sent to me for payment.
I agree to support other learners as appropriate within the organisation, to present the results of my work both in house and externally on request and share my learning with others.
I agree that I may be individually liable for further charges incurred in the event of (such as re- submissions, extensions to courses)

What are you proposing to change?
The harmonisation of legacy Trust induction policies from all MSE sites
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
The standardisation of Trust induction will provide reassurance that all new MSE colleagues are receiving the same high quality information.
Who benefits from this change and how?
